author: JOHN GUERRA Staff Writer
title: Defendants grew up with murder victim | Highlands News-Sun | midfloridanewspapers.com
text:
As first-degree murder defendant Jyer ‘Markis Jenkins, 20, walked from a holding cell and into Highlands County Circuit Court Judge David Ward’s courtroom in Sebring on Monday morning, more than a dozen relatives and friends were in the spectators gallery to show support.
The Lake Placid residents were not in the courtroom to support Jenkins, but to seek justice for Elijah Daley, the young man Jenkins and four others are accused of murdering at the Lake Placid Ramada Inn on May 8. Jenkins and four others – La’Niyah Nevaeh McLeod, 19, of North Port; J’Mari Mitchell, 18, of Lake Placid; Yoshabelle “Yoshi” Edouard, 19, of Port Charlotte; and Latarius Lamar Johnson, 26, of Lake Placid entered not guilty pleas in Daley’s murder. Detectives believe the five defendants – whom Daley knew well – set him up to be robbed at gunpoint in the Ramada motel room.

author: BP Editor 7
title: Climbers trapped by flash flood on Mount Kinabalu, no injuries reported (Video)
text:
Screengrab shows rapid water rushing down the Mount Kinabalu climbing route as climbers make their way down.
KOTA KINABALU (July 10): Several climbers were trapped on Mount Kinabalu following heavy rain and a flash flood this morning.
No injuries were reported in the incident.
Video footage circulating online showed climbers clinging to ropes while making their way down the mountain as fast-moving waters cascaded down around them.
A statement on the official Mount Kinabalu Facebook page said weather conditions began to deteriorate early in the morning, with continuous rainfall causing the climbing route to become dangerously slippery — particularly near streams and rocky sections.
Sabah Parks has since issued a safety advisory, urging all climbers to strictly follow safety instructions and to never proceed without the supervision of an accredited mountain guide.
A malim gunung (mountain guide), who declined to be named, said such occurrences are not unusual during heavy downpours.
“Every time it rains heavily, there’s a real risk of flash floods. The trail becomes extremely slippery. We always advise climbers to stop and seek shelter when conditions turn dangerous,” he said.
He also reminded climbers to always carry rain gear and basic safety equipment, as well as to never attempt the climb alone or without a guide.
As of this afternoon, no untoward incidents have been reported.
Sabah Parks is continuing to monitor weather conditions to ensure the safety of climbers still on the mountain.
Standing at 4,095 metres, Mount Kinabalu is a popular climbing destination for both domestic and international adventurers.
However, weather conditions remain a critical factor in ensuring the safety and success of any climb.

author: Pam Robinson
title: Wind Brings Early End to Holiday Spectacular
text:
By Pam Robinson ,
7 days ago A forecast of heavy winds brought an early end to the Huntington Holiday Spectacular Thursday evening.
The Wall Street display with its many decorations was oriiginally supposed to run through Thursday night and then be removed starting Friday.
“Unfortunately, due to today’s high winds, we had to begin taking down the Holiday Spectacular a day earlier than planned to ensure everyone’s safety. Thank you all for making this holiday season so special, and a big thank you to Northwell Health for their incredible support,” organizers said on Facebook.
Gusts up to 31 mph were possible overnight, the National Weather Service said.
Town of Huntington photo
Parade Opens Huntington’s Holiday Spectacular
Town Board OKs Holiday Spectacular Plans
Northwell Funding Helps Move Holiday Spectacular Back to Wall Street
1

author: ESTHER OLUKA
title: Uganda Martyrs' Day celebrations must prioritise faith, Archbishop insists | Monitor
text: Uganda Martyrs' Day celebrations must prioritise faith, Archbishop insists What you need to know: While giving an update on the level of preparations, Wokorach, who has been serving as the Bishop of the Nebbi Catholic Diocese, told journalists on Friday, May 31, during a media briefing held at Uganda Catholic Secretariat, in Nsambya, in Kampala, that Namugongo risks becoming anything else apart from a spiritual center The archbishop designate of Gulu Catholic Archdiocese Raphael P’Mony Wokorach has said the Uganda Martyrs' Day celebrations should only be accompanied by faith and spiritual activities and nothing else. While giving an update on the level of preparations, Wokorach, who has been serving as the Bishop of the Nebbi Catholic Diocese, told journalists on Friday, May 31, during a media briefing held at Uganda Catholic Secretariat, in Nsambya, in Kampala, that Namugongo risks becoming anything else apart from a spiritual center. "We risk Namugongo becoming anything other than a spiritual center. As we prepare, you feel pressure from all sides... The politicians come to help us (but under conditions) and say, "I must appear there," but that's part of the pressure. Each year, the celebration is held in Namugongo, a township in Wakiso district, with prayers at both the Catholic Shrine of Uganda Martyrs and the Anglican Martyrs' Site. “Let us not draw our attention away from what we are meant to be. Pilgrimage is not a journey for fun but rather a spiritual and religious one that one hopes to benefit from. Let the pressure of the world not overwhelm and evade what Namugongo initially was," Wokorach elaborated. Overall, Namugongo celebrations should be protected from all invasions of ideas, the archbishop-elect said. “Namugongo celebrations should be protected from all invasions of ideas and how to look at them... We come together as a nation to celebrate the spiritual life of these Uganda Martyrs, and that is what I say we should protect. That should not be lost on our side. If we don’t look at the Uganda Martyrs as holy people who lived because of God, then we have lost it all,” he said. Nebbi Catholic Diocese is animating this year’s Martyrs Day celebrations under the theme, “But as for me and my household, we shall serve the Lord.” The team is working with a budget of Shs 1.8 billion. Head of the Finance Committee for the Nebbi Catholic Diocese Namugongo preparations Mr Maurice Opar Manano revealed during the press briefing that the government of Uganda had been the biggest financial contributor to the event after giving them Shs 1.1 Billion. Other entities including organisations and individuals have additionally made contributions in one way or another. “The collections in total so far are Shs 1.7 billion against Shs1.8 billion, meaning our deficit is Shs 100 million which is negligible,” Mr Manano said. “The ideas of the committee for the event and the proposed budget were all initiated last year in June 2023 but since then, prices for items have increased and everything else has changed. We have struggled to see if everything fits within the budget,” Mr. Manano added. On the challenges, the organising team said the huge numbers of pilgrims sometimes tend to complicate matters. "We are simply moving from being a national celebration to an international celebration. Each year, more people come from outside the country. With the growth in numbers, preparations also become very complex from the budget and everything else including issues of security, food, and so forth,” Wokorach said. Amidst everything else, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Uganda Tourism Board (UTB) Lilly Ajarova said the Martyrs Day celebrations come with the blessings of positioning Uganda as a faith-based destination, which is a plus for the country in so many dimensions including enhancing the country’s tourism capabilities. Above everything else, the team says they are all set for the coming celebrations.

organizations.name: gulu catholic archdiocese raphael p’mony wokorach

author: Matthew Sparkes
title: Oil extraction may have triggered over 100 earthquakes in the UK
text:
Earthquakes that occurred near an oil extraction site in Surrey, UK, in 2018 and 2019 had been put down to coincidence, but a new analysis with an updated look at the geology of the area suggests the seismic events may indeed have been linked to drilling The Horse Hill oil site was discovered in 2015 Invicta Kent Media/Shutterstock
Over 100 earthquakes that shook the south of England are likely to have been triggered by oil extraction, say experts. Previous research had ruled out a link, but fresh information about the geology of the area has established a probable connection.
The earthquakes were all fairly minor, measuring between 1.34 and 3.18 on the Richter scale, and took place near Newdigate in Surrey in 2018 and 2019. Residents reported their houses shaking for several seconds.
Advertisement
There was speculation at the time that the earthquakes were linked to oil extraction by UK Oil & Gas, although the epicentre of the earthquakes was between 5 kilometres and 10 kilometres from the company's Horse Hill drilling site. But previous research by the British Geological Survey (BGS) and others determined that the earthquakes, while rare and relatively near to the drilling, were natural and coincidental.
Now, Matthew Fox and Philip Meredith at University College London have taken another look, using the latest understanding of the rock makeup of the area, and suggest that the earthquakes were indeed induced by oil extraction.
The pair ran more than a million computer simulations based on the…
Matthew Sparkes

author: di Iacopo Scaramuzzi
title: Monsignor Paglia: "Quanti corvi che speculano sul Papa, chiediamoci se lo proteggiamo abbastanza" - la Repubblica
text:
CITTÀ DEL VATICANO – In giro ci sono «corvi» che speculano sui malanni del Papa , ma Francesco parla, scherza, ha voglia di reagire. «C’è bisogno di lui» e non bisognerà attendere tanto per rivederlo in Vaticano. Ne è convinto monsignor Vincenzo Paglia, presidente della Pontificia accademia per la vita.
?«Io ho notizie positive. Mi auguro che il Papa possa guarire presto perché c’è bisogno di lui. C’è bisogno che possa riprendere pienamente la sua vita di pastore della Chiesa, che in questo tempo è più che preziosa: vediamo il mondo che forse ha qualche resipiscenza sulla tragedia della guerra, ma può essere aiutato a comprendere la giustizia, la dignità, i diritti e i doveri della famiglia umana. Questo Papa è necessario».
Francesco si è esposto a impegni giubilari e bagni di folla.
«Sì ma questo è papa Francesco. Certo uno dei problemi della sua salute è la non curanza che a volte manifesta verso la stessa. E forse ci dovrebbe essere maggiore solerzia da parte di tutti noi a proteggerlo. Io comunque la prima lezione che traggo da questa sua esagerazione è quella di interrogarci sulle nostre esagerazioni contrarie: troppa cura di se stessi e poca cura delle relazioni con gli altri».
Il Papa in effetti la sera chiama la parrocchia di Gaza.
«In un mondo che vive del virtuale questo sta a dire quanto tenga alle relazioni dirette e immediate, fino all’esagerazione».
Giorgia Meloni ha riferito di averlo trovato vigile e sempre dotato di senso dell’umorismo.
«Mi fa molto piacere, anche perché non mancano i corvi, e sapere che il Papa continua anche a scherzare mi pare una notizia utile per tutti».
Quando parla di corvi si riferisce alle fake news che girano sull’aggravarsi del Papa?
«Sì, e non solo. Guardiamo con maggiore positività a questo momento».
Ma se guarirà ce la farà il Papa con tutti impegni del giubileo a continuare a governare?
«Quando ha cominciato a stare sulla sedia a rotelle qualcuno ha chiesto al Papa se poteva ancora governare, e Francesco ha ricordato l’episodio del cardinale Marchetti Selvaggiani, al quale un monsignore mandato da Pio XI domandò la stessa cosa, e il cardinale rispose: dica a chi lo ha mandato che Roma si governa con la testa e non con i piedi. La Chiesa non è anzitutto un’organizzazione, la Chiesa si governa facendo risplendere il primato dell’amore per gli altri».
Secondo lei quando tornerà il Papa in Vaticano?
«Non sono un medico ma immagino che non bisognerà aspettare molto. E mi auguro che sia molto più attento lui e tutti noi a moderare, diciamo così, i suoi eccessi di impegno. Tutti sappiamo quanto il contatto diretto con la gente sia per lui davvero vita. Del resto era quello che capitava a Gesù, quando scese dal monte tutti volevano toccarlo perché da lui usciva una forza straordinaria che aiutava e guariva».
Ma a 88 anni e con i germi che girano il contatto è pericoloso.
«Esatto: mi auguro che gli altri lo aiutino… Allo stesso tempo sono sicuro che accadrà quello che avvenne quando gli apostoli cercarono di frenare Gesù con i bambini: lasciate che vengano a me».
Intanto la Chiesa prega: il cardinale vicario Reina ha invitato i fedeli della diocesi di Roma a pregare per la salute del Papa.
«Bene ha fatto a esortare la Chiesa di Roma a pregare per il suo pastore. Questo è accaduto fin dall’inizo, come narrano gli Atti degli apostoli quando San Pietro era in carcere. Non che il Gemelli sia un carcere! Però è doveroso che i fedeli preghino per lui. E da malato il Papa invita a riscoprire la forza della preghiera, non solo per sé, anche per tutti coloro che soffrono, pensiamo alle guerre, ai malati, agli anziani soli».
Leggi i commenti I commenti dei lettori
